title: A Big Goodbye for a Music Star in Manchester
summary: Gary "Mani" Mounfield was a famous bass player in bands like The Stone Roses and Primal Scream. He passed away, and many people came to say goodbye at a funeral in Manchester. His family, friends, and fans gathered at Manchester Cathedral. Famous musicians like Ian Brown, Bobby Gillespie, Liam Gallagher, and Paul Weller were there. Even soccer stars Sir David Beckham and Gary Neville came. Fans lined the streets to watch the funeral procession from his home to the cathedral. Ian Brown, his bandmate, gave a speech calling Mani a beautiful person and a brother. He suggested building a big gold statue of Mani in the city. Fans clapped and wore special hats and T-shirts to honor him. Mani's coffin had artwork from his band's album and a Manchester United scarf. He was known for his happy spirit and great music.

background_read: Gary "Mani" Mounfield was a musician from England who played bass guitar. He was in popular bands like The Stone Roses and Primal Scream, which were famous in the 1980s and 1990s for their music style called "baggy." Manchester is a city in England where many musicians come from. Funerals are events where people gather to remember and say goodbye to someone who has died. Statues are built to honor important people. Fans are people who really like a musician or band and show support by attending events or wearing special clothes.
